description.narrative: The overall goal of the proposed projects to enhance resilience to drought of communities, institutions and ecosystems in the IGAD region. Building on the on-going support from Sweden and other development partners; and with the benefit of the experiences and lessons learnt from implementation of the first phase of the IDDRSI Strategy (2013 – 2018), the IGAD Secretariat will use the proposed project to consolidate its work in the promotion and coordination of resilience-building activities in the IGAD region by focusing on the following areas:(a) Optimising the implementation of IDDRSI;(b) Scaling up resilience-enhancing technologies and innovations in cross-border areas;(c) Gender mainstreaming, capacity development and partnership needed to achieve the objectives of IDDRSI and(d) Improving IGAD’s capacity to monitor, analyse and evaluate the process of attaining resilience-enhancement.

Detta bidrag bygger på ett pågående stöd från Sverige och andra utvecklingspartner. Det syftar till att konsolidera IDDRSIs (IGAD Drought Disaster Resilience and Sustainability Initiative) uppnådda resultat vad gäller främjande och samordning av motståndskraft (resiliens) i IGAD-regionen genom att fokusera på följande områden: (a) Optimera genomförandet av IDDRSI; b) Förbättra teknik för att förbättra resiliens och innovationer i gränsområden, c) Integrering av jämställdhetsperspektiv, kapacitetsutveckling och partnerskap som behövs för att uppnå målen med IDDRSI, och d) Förbättra IGADs förmåga att övervaka, analysera och utvärdera processen att uppnå stärkande av motståndskraft.
Det föreslagna projektet löper över 3 år (oktober 2019 - september 2022) och har en sammanlagd kostnad på 56 500 000 kronor varav 23 200 000 kronor är avsedda att genomföras år 1 (oktober 2019 - september 2020), 17 400 000 kronor för år 2 (oktober 2020 - september 2021) och 15 900 000 kronor för år 3 (oktober 2021 - september 2022).

description.narrative: This is the second year of implementation for the project which has a duration of three years. During the reporting period, the project has achieved the following. a) Optimising the implementation of IDDRSI - Key indicators for monitoring the mainstreaming and implementation of CPP and RPP components in National Development Plans, identified for all the IDDRSI priority intervention areas (PIAs). This was done for all countries. - Ensured the functioning national and sub-national coordination with 25 and 39 episodes of Steering Committee meetings, respectively. The importance of national and sub-national coordination for effective implementation of IDDRSI is increasingly getting appreciated. - The 12th meeting of the IDDRSI Platform Steering Committee and the 7th IDDRSI Platform General Assembly were held in Mombasa, with an option for virtual participation. The meetings acknowledged the effectiveness of IDDRSI as a programming framework for regional cooperation in development and re-affirmed the commitment of Member States and Development Partners to increase investments in resilienceenhancement interventions. It was agreed to hold a Resilience Summit and Investment Conference during 2022. Consultations are on-going to select a date during the suggested period of June November 2022. (b) Scaling up resilience-enhancing technologies and innovations in crossborder areas Sammanfattande resultatuppdatering Conclusion on Performance Contribution ID: 13268 2 (9) - 56 technologies of relevance to resilience-enhancement in a cross-border setting and amenable for exploitation in the IGAD region were identified in a rapid assessment study. A plan covering the next steps for determining the most viable and feasible of the identified technologies, including the modalities of their implementation, has been developed. (c) Gender mainstreaming, capacity development and partnership needed to achieve the objectives of IDDRSI - 8 policy briefs (one for each IDDRSI priority intervention area) were prepared. These will be printed and published for wider circulation, to enhance understanding of IDDRSI programming. - 24 episodes of radio program presentations on gender and resilience were aired in the Karamoja and Mandera Clusters, highlighting issues of gender in resilience building and popularising IDDRSI, with a focus on gender inequalities in the contexts of drought resilience, covid-19 and the economic and financial inclusion of women were discussed. - A Gender and Resilience Working was established in 2020 to support the mainstreaming of gender perspectives in IDDRSI at regional and Member State levels. The first face to face coordination meeting was held in Bishoftu, Ethiopia from 13-15 September 2021 to i) Orient members of GRWG on new IDDRSI planning frameworks at regional and country levels; ii) Review progress, achievements, challenges and lessons for the GRWG in 2020/2021; iii) Develop GRWG plans for 2021/2022. The meeting was attended by 15 participants (8 females and 7 males). At the end of the three-day meeting, the group members developed understanding about the role of the group, particularly in relation to its role in IDDRSI. Finally, the GRWG members developed annual work plan through a facilitated process. - A combined Gender and Resilience Knowledge Share Fair on 16-18 September 2021 in Bishoftu, Ethiopia under the theme Good Practices in Mainstreaming Gender in Cross-Border Resilience Interventions in Karamoja and Mandera Clusters. The meeting was attended by 83 participants (29 female). (d) Improving IGADs capacity to monitor, analyse and evaluate the process of attaining resilience-enhancement - The 57th Greater Horn of Africa Climate Outlook Forum (GHACOF) was successfully held online in which the seasonal forecast for the period March-May 2021 for the IGAD region was presented along with a guide for decision makers in various climate-sensitive sectors. - An IGAD food security, nutrition and resilience information system framework has been developed. The framework is expected to form the foundation for the operationalization and sustenance of an IGAD food security, nutrition and resilience Sammanfattande resultatuppdatering Conclusion on Performance Contribution ID: 13268 3 (9) information system, which is proposed to serve three main purposes (components): a) Routine monitoring and early warning, b) Periodic or seasonal analysis and c) Data depository for action research. There are plans to further review the framework in consultation with member states. - In collaboration with FAO, IFRAH (IGAD Food Security, Nutrition and Resilience Analysis Hub) organized monthly Food Security and Nutrition Working Group meetings that provided a platform for sharing of information around food security, nutrition, livestock, climate, markets, displacement and conflict among others. Each meeting was followed by a monthly statement on the prevailing food security and nutrition situation, underlying drivers and recommended actions, which was shared widely with partners in the region. - IFRAH, in collaboration with IPC Global Support Unit (GSU) Eastern and Central Africa, has convened three IGAD Bi-annual meetings on food security and nutrition on 29th June 2020, 10th November 2020 and 13-14 September 2021 to provide a forum for Member States and partners to jointly discuss the food security and nutrition situation in the region, and to propose practical response actions for decision makers in support of improved food security and nutrition across the region. 1.3 Assessment of the likelihood that the objectives will be achieved by the end of the intervention given the overall risk It is assessed that the project is on track to achieve its objectives. During the first and second year of implementation, activities were delayed by COVID-19 pandemic but IGAD was able to revert to digital forums and used alternative approaches to carry out planned activities. As COVID-19 restrictions are relaxed in the region, the associated risk level is changed from medium to low. A project steering committee meeting was held on March 22, 2022 in Djibouti (IGAD office - CEPCVE). The progress made so far was positively assessed and some indications of request for a continued support from Sweden were presented.
